Morera's theorem

Suppose that f ⁣:C→C\func{f}{\C}{\C}f:C→C is continuous on C\CC and holomorphic on C∖R={z∈C∣z∉R}\C \setminus \R = \set{z \in \C \mid z \notin \R}C∖R={z∈C∣z∈/R}. Prove that fff is entire.
Solution.

By Morera's theorem, it's enough to show that the circulation of fff around any rectangle RRR is 000. Let R=[a,b]×[ic,id]R = \br{a, b} \times \br{ic, id}R=[a,b]×[ic,id]. If R∩R=∅R \cap \R = \emptysetR∩R=∅, then by connectedness, the rectangle lies entirely in C∖R\C \setminus \RC∖R, so by Cauchy's theorem, ∫∂Rf(z) dz=0\int_{\partial R} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = 0∫∂R​f(z)dz=0.

Now suppose R∩R≠∅R \cap \R \neq \emptysetR∩R=∅ and let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0. Consider the rectangles Rε+=[a,b]×[ic,−iε]R_\epsilon^+ = \br{a, b} \times \br{ic, -i\epsilon}Rε+​=[a,b]×[ic,−iε] and Rε−=[a,b]×[iε,id]R_\epsilon^- = \br{a, b} \times \br{i\epsilon, id}Rε−​=[a,b]×[iε,id] with boundaries oriented counter-clockwise. Observe that both of these rectangles lie entirely in C∖R\C \setminus \RC∖R, so

∫∂Rε+f(z) dz=∫∂Rε−f(z) dz=0\int_{\partial R_\epsilon^+} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = \int_{\partial R_\epsilon^-} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = 0∫∂Rε+​​f(z)dz=∫∂Rε−​​f(z)dz=0

by Cauchy's theorem. Let Uε=[a,b]×{iε}U_\epsilon = \br{a, b} \times \set{i\epsilon}Uε​=[a,b]×{iε} oriented from left to right, i.e., the bottom edge of Rε+R_\epsilon^+Rε+​. Similarly, let Lε=[a,b]×{−iε}L_\epsilon = \br{a, b} \times \set{-i\epsilon}Lε​=[a,b]×{−iε} be oriented from right to left. We have

∫Uεf(z) dz=∫abf(t+iε) dtand∫Lεf(z) dz=−∫abf(t−iε) dt.\int_{U_\epsilon} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = \int_a^b f\p{t + i\epsilon} \,\diff{t} \quad\text{and}\quad \int_{L_\epsilon} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = -\int_a^b f\p{t - i\epsilon} \,\diff{t}.∫Uε​​f(z)dz=∫ab​f(t+iε)dtand∫Lε​​f(z)dz=−∫ab​f(t−iε)dt.

Since fff is continuous on the compact strip [a,b]×[−iε,iε]\br{a, b} \times \br{-i\epsilon, i\epsilon}[a,b]×[−iε,iε], it is uniformly continuous on this strip. Thus, for any η>0\eta > 0η>0, if ε\epsilonε is small enough, then ∣f(t+iε)−f(t−iε)∣<η\abs{f\p{t + i\epsilon} - f\p{t - i\epsilon}} < \eta∣f(t+iε)−f(t−iε)∣<η uniformly in t∈[a,b]t \in \br{a, b}t∈[a,b]. Hence, for small enough ε\epsilonε,

∣∫Uε+Lεf(z) dz∣≤∫ab∣f(t+iε)−f(t−iε)∣ dt≤η(b−a).\abs{\int_{U_\epsilon+L_\epsilon} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} \leq \int_a^b \abs{f\p{t + i\epsilon} - f\p{t - i\epsilon}} \,\diff{t} \leq \eta\p{b - a}.∣∣​∫Uε​+Lε​​f(z)dz∣∣​≤∫ab​∣f(t+iε)−f(t−iε)∣dt≤η(b−a).

Hence, the contributions from UεU_\epsilonUε​ and LεL_\epsilonLε​ cancel out as ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0. It follows that

∫∂Rf(z) dz=lim⁡ε→0(∫Rε+f(z) dz+∫Rε−f(z) dz)=0,\int_{\partial R} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = \lim_{\epsilon\to0} \p{\int_{R_\epsilon^+} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} + \int_{R_\epsilon^-} f\p{z} \,\diff{z}} = 0,∫∂R​f(z)dz=ε→0lim​(∫Rε+​​f(z)dz+∫Rε−​​f(z)dz)=0,

so fff is entire.
